questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia


Lewy body dementia is a progressive and irreversible neurodegenerative disorder.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. B12 deficiency: Reversible with supplementation.
 

Option B. Normal pressure hydrocephalus: Reversible with shunting.
 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Reversible with thyroid hormone replacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy body dementia is not a reversible cause of dementia.

questions.text: A patient working in an iron factory presents with visual disturbance and is found to have iron deposits in the eye. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this ocular finding?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Siderosis bulbi

 

Siderosis bulbi is the condition where iron gets deposited in the eye due to the entry of an iron foreign body. This is commonly seen in industrial settings where iron is frequently used.

 

Ocular changes includes heterochromia (change in the color of the iris), iron deposits in the lens, uvea, and retina, leading to conditions like uveitis, retinitis, and even optic atrophy. These changes can result in severe visual impairment and blindness.

 

The condition can present immediately after the injury or even years later.

 

Severe cases can lead to phthisis bulbi, a condition where the eye becomes shrunken and non-functional.

 

The investigation of choice for detecting an iron foreign body is a CT scan or a B-scan ultrasound, as MRI is contraindicated due to the magnetic nature of iron.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chalcosis: This condition is caused by copper deposition in the eye. It is seen in cases involving copper foreign bodies.

 

Option C. Kayser-Fleischer ring: This is a brownish ring around the cornea seen in Wilson's disease, a condition involving copper metabolism disorder.

 

Option D. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a genetic disorder causing pigmentary dystrophy of the retina. It does not involve iron deposits and is unrelated to the occupational exposure described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Siderosis bulbi is caused by iron deposits in the eye, commonly seen in patients with a history of iron foreign body exposure, leading to significant ocular changes and potential blindness.

questions.text: Identify the marked segment of liver. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V

 

Marked structure is Segment V of liver.

 

 

The liver is divided into eight anatomical segments based on the Couinaud classification system. Each segment has its own vascular and biliary supply.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver is divided into eight anatomical segments according to the Couinaud classification

choices.text: Echocardiography for cardiac disease
Urine analysis for bacteriuria
Blood sugar levels for GDM
VDRL for syphilis

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

 

Explanation:

 

Echocardiography for cardiac disease is not part of routine antenatal screening. While it is important for detecting cardiac conditions, echocardiography is typically performed only if there is a known or suspected cardiac disease. Routine screening for all antenatal mothers does not include echocardiography due to its cost and the specific indications required for its use.

 

Routine antenatal screening is designed to identify common conditions that may affect the health of the mother and baby.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Urine analysis for bacteriuriaUrine analysis for bacteriuria: This test is routinely performed to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria, which, if left untreated, can lead to urinary tract infections and increase the risk of preterm labor.

 

Option C. Blood sugar levels for GDM Blood sugar levels for GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus): Screening for GDM is essential to identify women who develop diabetes during pregnancy, which can affect both maternal and fetal health.

 

Option D. VDRL for syphilis: The VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is a screening tool for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection that can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby if left untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine antenatal screening does not include echocardiography for cardiac disease unless there is a known or suspected condition.

 

Ref: Page no 110, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text:
What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

Central cord lesions, such as those seen in conditions like syringomyelia and intramedullary tumors, present with a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the anatomical arrangement of the spinal tracts.

 

1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs: This pattern is common in central cord syndromes, where there is damage to the anterior horn cells leading to lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions in the upper limbs. As the condition progresses, upper motor neuron (UMN) signs may appear in the lower limbs due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.

 

3. Bladder and bowel involvement: Central cord lesions can affect autonomic functions leading to bladder and bowel dysfunction, especially in cases of extensive or progressive lesions like intramedullary tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs: This pattern is not typical for central cord syndromes. Usually, the upper limbs show LMN signs due to the involvement of the anterior horn cells, and the lower limbs show UMN signs.

 

4. Posterior tract involvement: Posterior tracts, which carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioception, are usually spared in central cord syndromes. These tracts are located more dorsally in the spinal cord, away from the central lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central cord lesions, such as syringomyelia, typically present with LMN signs in the upper limbs, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and can involve bladder and bowel dysfunction, but they do not typically affect the posterior tracts

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary healing

 

The x-ray shows a fracture that has been treated with plating. This suggests the fracture is undergoing primary healing, which occurs when there is rigid fixation (such as with plates). In primary healing, no callus formation is seen because the bone edges are closely approximated and there is minimal micromotion. Healing occurs through direct bone formation, and intramembranous ossification can be part of this process. However, the overall mechanism here is primary healing, which is specifically associated with rigid internal fixation like plating.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creeping substitution: This refers to a bone graft healing mechanism where old bone is replaced by new bone. It does not apply to fracture healing in the context of this case.

 

Option B. Intramembranous ossification: While intramembranous ossification can be involved in primary bone healing, it is not the comprehensive mechanism. The broader term is primary healing, which includes processes like intramembranous ossification but is driven by rigid fixation.

 

Option D. Secondary healing: This involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion at the fracture site, as seen with casting or nailing. This is not applicable in this case, where rigid fixation (plating) is used, leading to primary healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation. Secondary healing involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion, typically seen with casts or nailing.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

 

  • The ECG shows supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).
  • The patient is also hemodynamically unstable, as indicated by the low blood pressure (70/40 mm Hg) and feeble pulse.
  • When a patient presents with SVT and hemodynamic instability, immediate rhythm conversion is essential.
  • The recommended treatment in such cases is direct current (DC) cardioversion.
  • This involves delivering an electric shock to the heart to restore a normal rhythm and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV adenosine: Adenosine temporarily slows or stops the heart's electrical activity and is often the first-line treatment for terminating stable, narrow complex supraventricular tachycardias (SVT). However, in hemodynamically unstable patients, its short-lived effects make it less suitable.

 

Option B. IV diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the rate in atrial fibrillation or flutter and certain types of SVT. In hemodynamically unstable patients, slowing the heart rate without converting the rhythm can be dangerous.

 

Option D. Ibutilide: Ibutilide is an antiarrhythmic drug used to treat certain types of atrial fibrillation or flutter. It's not the first-line treatment for hemodynamically unstable SVT and carries a risk of proarrhythmia, meaning it can sometimes cause new or worsening rhythm problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and hemodynamic instability, direct current (DC) cardioversion is the recommended and most effective treatment.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1744

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Latanoprost is a Prostaglandin, PGF2α analog, that acts in glaucoma by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor and is used as a first line drug in patients with open angle glaucoma. It can be safely used in bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchospasm as a systemic side effect. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option B. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog used for the termination of pregnancy. It is not relevant for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with a history of burn wound on the lower limb. His wound is given in the picture. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marjolin's Ulcer

 

The patient has a history of a burn wound on the lower limb. The image shows a chronic wound with changes typical of Marjolin's ulcer. Marjolin's ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in chronic wounds. This transformation is due to chronic irritation to the skin, which increases the risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Venous Ulcer: This is incorrect because venous ulcers typically occur in patients with chronic venous insufficiency and are usually located on the medial aspect of the ankle.

 

Option C. Arterial Ulcer: This is incorrect because arterial ulcers are associated with peripheral arterial disease and are usually found on the toes, feet, or lateral aspect of the ankle.

 

Option D. Infected burn wound: This is incorrect because an infected burn wound would not necessarily show the chronic changes typical of Marjolin's ulcer, which includes malignant transformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marjolin's ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in chronic wounds, including long-standing burn wounds.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

 

  • The above image shows the seeds of Semicarpus anacardium
  • Identification: Black, heart-shaped seeds with a rough projection at the base
  • Active principles: bhilawanol and semicarpol.
  • Common name: Marking nut
  • Uses of the juice:
    • To produce an artificial bruise.
    • Juice is used by washerman/laundries to inscribe identification number on the clothes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ricin: Ricin is a highly toxic protein found in the seeds of the castor oil plant (Ricinus communis).

 

Option C. Abrin: Abrin is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius).

 

Option D. Calotropin: Calotropin is a cardiac glycoside found in the milkweed plant (Calotropis gigantea).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active principle of the marking nut (Semicarpus anacardium) is Bhilawanol, used in traditional practices for its staining and toxic properties.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the below condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warfarin

 

The figure shows clinical picture of dermal vascular necrosis, also known as ‘purple toe syndrome’. It is an early adverse effect of warfarin. It is seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.

 

Dermal Vascular Necrosis

 

  • Warfarin-induced dermal vascular necrosis is a rare complication of warfarin therapy.
  • It characterized by the development of painful skin lesions in patients taking warfarin.
  • It is thought to be caused by a transient hypercoagulable state resulting from a rapid reduction in protein C levels in patients with underlying protein C deficiency or other risk factors.
  • The lesions typically occur in areas with a high concentration of adipose tissue, such as the breasts, thighs, and buttocks.
  • The initial symptoms include red or purple spots on the skin that can quickly progress to painful, necrotic lesions with a central blister or eschar.
  • The diagnosis is usually made clinically based on the characteristic appearance of the lesions and the patient's history of warfarin therapy.
  • The treatment of dermal vascular necrosis involves stopping warfarin and initiating alternative anticoagulant therapy, such as heparin or low molecular weight heparin.
  • In severe cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to remove the necrotic tissue and prevent further damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by activating antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis. However, heparin can cause other complications such as heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

Option C. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor used as an anticoagulant. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is generally associated with a different profile of side effects, including bleeding.

 

Option D. Rivaroxaban: Rivaroxaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor used for anticoagulation. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is associated with a different side effect profile, mainly related to bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin can cause dermal vascular necrosis, particularly in patients with protein C deficiency, presenting as painful, necrotic skin lesions shortly after initiation of therapy.

questions.text: Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bladder exstrophy

 

The above image is suggestive of ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy.

 

Ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. Clinical features of this condition include separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis, epispadias, and genital defects such as bifid clitoris in females and broad and short penis with bilateral inguinal hernia in males.

 

Management of bladder exstrophy involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. The first step is closure of the abdominal and bladder wall within the first year of life. This procedure may require an iliac osteotomy to relieve tension on the bladder and facilitate wound-healing. Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects may be performed. Alternatively, urinary diversion can be carried out by creating ureterosigmoid anastomosis, an ileal or colonic conduit, or continent urinary diversion.

 

Long-term complications of bladder exstrophy include stricture at the site of the anastomosis leading to bilateral hydronephrosis and infection, hyperchloremic acidosis, and an increased (20-fold) risk of tumor formation such as adenoma and adenocarcinoma at the site of a ureteroscopic anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: The abdominal contents are out and are covered in a sac. It is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect. It occurs due to the failure of the physiological umbilical hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. It is associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels and chromosomal abnormalities.

 

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct: It is a congenital anomaly that occurs during fetal development. The vitelline duct is a structure that connects the developing embryo to the yolk sac. In normal development, the vitelline duct is supposed to disappear by the time the fetus is born. However, in some cases, the duct persists and can lead to various complications.

 

Option D. gastrochisis: in this condition, the abdominal contents are out and are NOT covered in a sac.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. The management involves staged surgical reconstruction, and complications include strictures, hyperchloremic acidosis, and increased risk of tumors.

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guidelines in 2016, recommending a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality. This guideline is structured to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy:

 

  1. 1st Trimester:
    • Contact 1: up to 12 weeks
  2. 2nd Trimester:
    • Contact 2: at 20 weeks
    • Contact 3: at 26 weeks
  3. 3rd Trimester:
    • Contact 4: at 30 weeks
    • Contact 5: at 34 weeks
    • Contact 6: at 36 weeks
    • Contact 7: at 38 weeks
    • Contact 8: at 40 weeks

 

These visits are designed to monitor the health of the mother and fetus, provide timely interventions, and offer essential health education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.

 

Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

choices.text: pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L
pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L
pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg
pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with labored breathing. ECG shows tall tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L

 

The patient with chronic renal failure presenting with sudden collapse and labored breathing is indicative of a severe acid-base disturbance, most likely metabolic acidosis. The tall tented T waves on the ECG suggest hyperkalemia, a common finding in metabolic acidosis and renal failure.

 

Patients with chronic renal failure often have a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of uremic toxins. The lab values in pH - 7.14, pCO2 - 20 mm Hg, HCO3 - 5 mEq/L indicate a severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. The low bicarbonate level confirms metabolic acidosis, and the low pCO2 indicates compensatory hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L: This combination is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis because the bicarbonate level is high, which would not be seen in metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg: This represents metabolic alkalosis or compensated respiratory acidosis, neither of which are consistent with the clinical picture of chronic renal failure and hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg: This reflects a normal pH, which would not be seen in the acute setting described, especially with the presence of severe symptoms and hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with chronic renal failure are at risk for high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In cases of sudden collapse with labored breathing and ECG changes like tall tented T waves, metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an inhibitor of ATP binding cassette efflux pumps? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Verapamil

 

Verapamil is known to inhibit the activity of ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters, such as P-glycoprotein, which is one of the most well-studied drug efflux transporters. By inhibiting P-glycoprotein, verapamil can increase the intracellular concentration of various drugs, which is why it is sometimes used as a pharmacokinetic enhancer to improve drug absorption and decrease drug clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tacrolimus: Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressant drug used mainly after allogeneic organ transplant to reduce the activity of the patient's immune system and lower the risk of organ rejection. It is not an inhibitor of the ATP-binding cassette efflux transporters.

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily to treat hypertension and angina pectoris. It is not known to inhibit ABC efflux transporters.

 

Option C. Diltiazem: Diltiazem, like verapamil, is a calcium channel blocker, but it is not as potent as verapamil in inhibiting P-glycoprotein. However, it does have some effect on drug efflux transporters, but to a lesser extent compared to verapamil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil is a known inhibitor of ATP-binding cassette transporters, particularly P-glycoprotein, and can be used to enhance the pharmacokinetics of various drugs by increasing their intracellular concentrations.

questions.text:
Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Ilizarov

  2. Uniplanar frame with one rod

  3. Biplanar frame

  4. Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.solution:
Ans. A. II, IV, III, I

 

EXTERNAL FIXATION

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin.

  • Uniplanar frame with one rod provides the least stability as it can only resist forces in one plane.

  • In uniplanar frame with two rods, adding a second rod increases stability compared to a single rod.

  • Biplanar frame provides stability in two planes, making it more secure than uniplanar frames. It improves the resistance to rotational and bending forces.

  • The Ilizarov external fixator is known for its exceptional stability due to its ring structure and multiple pins. It provides high axial and torsional stability.

  • It is often used for complex fractures and lengthening procedures.

  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done.

  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.

  • Therefore, the Ilizarov fixator offers the highest level of stability among the options listed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:

 

Uniplanar frame with one rod (II) < uniplanar frame with two rods (IV) < biplanar frame (III) < ilizarov (I)

questions.text: In which type of cataract surgery is suturing with 10-0 nylon performed? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra capsular cataract surgery

 

Explanation:

 

In extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE), a larger incision (approximately 10 to 12 millimeters) is made at the limbus to remove the lens nucleus in one piece. Due to the size of this incision, suturing is necessary to close the wound properly. The suturing is typically performed using 10-0 nylon monofilament. This method can involve interrupted sutures or continuous suturing to ensure the wound is securely closed and to promote proper healing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phacoemulsification: This technique involves making a much smaller incision (around 3 millimeters or less) through which the lens is emulsified and aspirated. Suturing is generally not required because the small incision is self-sealing.

 

Option B. FLACS (Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery): This advanced technique uses a femtosecond laser to create precise incisions and to perform capsulotomy and lens fragmentation. Similar to phacoemulsification, the incisions made are small and typically do not require suturing.

 

Option C. Manual small incision cataract surgery (SICS): In SICS, the incision size is between 6 to 8 millimeters. Depending on the quality of the incision and tunnel, suturing may or may not be required. Good surgical technique can often avoid the need for suturing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE) requires suturing with 10-0 nylon due to the larger incision size necessary for removing the lens nucleus in one piece.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DC shock

 

The patient presents with atrial fibrillation (AF) characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of well-defined P waves on the ECG. His vital signs indicate hemodynamic instability, specifically a low systolic blood pressure of 84 mm Hg (<90 mm HG).

 

Why DC Shock is Correct: DC shock (synchronized cardioversion) is indicated for patients with tachyarrhythmia who are hemodynamically unstable. Hemodynamic instability is evidenced by a systolic blood pressure below 90 mm Hg, which is a critical threshold indicating the need for immediate cardioversion to restore normal rhythm and improve cardiac output.

 

Steps for Decision Making:

 

  1. Identify the Rhythm: The ECG shows atrial fibrillation.
  2. Assess Stability: The patient's systolic blood pressure is 84 mm Hg, indicating instability.
  3. Treatment Protocol: Immediate synchronized cardioversion (DC shock) is necessary for unstable tachyarrhythmias.

 

Note - The three contraindications for using synchronized DC cardioversion are:

 

  1. Sinus tachycardia
  2. Multifocal atrial tachycardia
  3. Digitalis toxicity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is used for anticoagulation in AF to prevent thromboembolism. However, it does not address hemodynamic instability or the immediate need to correct the arrhythmia.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used for rate control in stable AF. They are inappropriate for acute management in hemodynamically unstable patients because they can further lower blood pressure and worsen instability.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used to convert AF to sinus rhythm, but it is not the first-line treatment in an unstable patient. Immediate cardioversion is preferred in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (e.g., systolic BP < 90 mm Hg), immediate synchronized cardioversion (DC shock) is the treatment of choice.

 

Rule of thumb: "If the patient is in shock, shock the patient."

questions.text: What is the airway management of choice in a patient with maxillofacial trauma after a road traffic accident? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

Explanation:

 

Tracheostomy is the preferred airway management technique in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma. This approach is chosen because severe facial injuries can make other forms of intubation difficult or impossible due to anatomical disruptions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orotracheal Intubation: Typically the first-line method in emergency airway management, it may be contraindicated or challenging in maxillofacial trauma due to the risk of causing further injury.

 

Option C. Nasotracheal Intubation: Avoided in maxillofacial injuries due to the risk of creating a false passage or worsening a basal skull fracture.

 

Option D. Oxygen Therapy: While important for providing oxygen, it does not secure the airway and is insufficient in cases of airway compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In severe maxillofacial trauma where the airway is compromised, an emergency tracheostomy is often necessary if orotracheal intubation is not feasible or safe due to the extent of the injuries.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

 

FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Treatment of femoral shaft fractures can be operative or non-operative.
  • Operative fixation with intramedullary nailing is the gold standard treatment.
  • Other operative techniques include plate osteosynthesis and external fixation.
  • Closed treatment with traction, splinting, and casting may be temporary treatment.

 

Intramedullary Nailing

 

  • Intramedullary nailing (IMN) is the gold standard of treatment for femoral shaft fractures.
  • Early treatment in a stable patient within 24-48 hours reduces the incidence of pulmonary complications, infection, and mortality.
  • Delayed treatment increases pulmonary complications in up to 56% of patients compared to only 16% of patients treated early.
  • The insertion site of an IMN is outside the zone of injury, preserving the surrounding blood flow and retain the hematoma that contains beneficial bone growth factors.
  • It provides a strong and stable internal fixation that allows for early mobilization and weight-bearing, which is crucial for promoting healing and preventing complications.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure compared to other options like plate fixation, resulting in less tissue disruption and blood loss.
  • It helps in a faster recovery time and a quicker return to daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip Spica: This is a cast that extends from the waist to the toes and is not typically used for femoral shaft fractures due to the limited mobility it allows.

 

Option B. Above Knee Slab: An above-knee slab is a temporary cast that can be used for pain management and swelling reduction but doesn't provide enough stability for healing a fractured femoral shaft.

 

Option C. Above Knee Cast: Similar to an above-knee slab, a cast offers limited stability and wouldn't be suitable for the long-term treatment of this fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, the second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and the third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:

 

  • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA).
  • APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion.
  • Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
  • The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Syphilis: Although syphilis can cause adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage and stillbirth, it is less likely than APLA to cause the combination of early pregnancy loss and early-onset preeclampsia described in this case.

 

Option C. TORCH infections: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) can lead to congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, and pregnancy loss. However, recurrent pregnancy loss due to TORCH infections is rare.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) typically affects pregnancies later in gestation and is associated with macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and other complications, but it is not commonly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss or early-onset preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss and complications such as early-onset preeclampsia, necessitating early delivery. Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical and laboratory criteria according to the Sapporo Criteria.

 

Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding increase in GFR? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase renal perfusion

 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is influenced by various factors, including the blood flow through the kidneys and the pressures within the glomerular capillaries. An increase in renal perfusion means an increase in blood flow to the kidneys, which enhances the filtration process and thereby increases the GFR. This can be achieved by dilation of the afferent arteriole (which increases blood flow into the glomerulus) or by constriction of the efferent arteriole (which increases the pressure within the glomerulus).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase resistance of afferent arteriole: Increasing the resistance of the afferent arteriole means constricting it, which would reduce blood flow into the glomerulus and subsequently decrease the GFR.

 

Option B. Decrease resistance of efferent arteriole: Decreasing the resistance of the efferent arteriole means dilating it, allowing blood to flow out of the glomerulus more easily. This reduces the pressure within the glomerulus, leading to a decrease in GFR.

 

Option C. Increase Bowman capsule hydrostatic pressure: Increasing the hydrostatic pressure within the Bowman's capsule would oppose the filtration pressure, leading to a decrease in GFR rather than an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing renal perfusion is the most effective way to increase the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21 hydroxylase deficiency

 

The clinical scenario describes a 3-year-old girl with ambiguous genitalia, specifically an enlarged clitoris, and a karyotype of 46XX. This presentation is indicative of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), which is most commonly caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

 

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of CAH and accounts for more than 95% of cases. This enzyme deficiency leads to impaired cortisol production, which results in an increased production of androgens. The excess androgens cause virilization, leading to ambiguous genitalia in genotypically female infants.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ambiguous genitalia: This includes an enlarged clitoris, which is often a sign of virilization due to increased androgens.
  • Karyotype 46XX: Confirms the genetic female status.
  • Increased serum androgens: Result from the enzyme deficiency and lead to masculinization of the external genitalia.

 

Clinical scenario: Ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 11 hydroxylase deficiency: This can also lead to CAH but is less common and typically presents with hypertension due to the accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone, which has mineralocorticoid activity.

 

Option C. 3 beta dehydrogenase deficiency: This is a rarer form of CAH and typically presents with both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiencies along with ambiguous genitalia in both sexes.

 

Option D. 2, 3 lyase deficiency: This is not a commonly recognized cause of CAH. The primary enzyme deficiencies leading to CAH are 21-hydroxylase, 11-hydroxylase, and 17-hydroxylase deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female (46XX) is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

questions.text: In a drowning case, primary relaxation is seen in all muscles except one group of muscles. What is this condition known as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cadaveric spasm

 

Typically, after death, there is a phase of primary relaxation in all muscles, followed by the onset of rigor mortis (stiffening of muscles). This primary relaxation phase usually lasts for about two hours. However, in certain cases, such as intense emotional or physical stress before death, cadaveric spasm can occur.

 

Cadaveric spasm, also known as instantaneous rigor, occurs immediately after death without any preceding relaxation phase. This condition is most commonly seen in the muscles of the hands and forearms. In the context of drowning, the hands may grasp objects such as grass or mud, reflecting the struggle for survival, and these objects may still be clutched post-mortem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of muscles that occurs several hours after death, following a period of primary relaxation. It affects all muscles sequentially and is not specific to any particular group of muscles immediately post-death.

 

Option C. Pugilistic attitude: The pugilistic attitude is a posture that results from the coagulation and contraction of muscles due to exposure to intense heat, such as in fire victims. It resembles a boxer's stance and is unrelated to drowning or primary muscle relaxation.

 

Option D. Washerwoman hand: Washerwoman hand refers to the wrinkling of the skin on the hands and feet after prolonged immersion in water. It is not related to muscle relaxation or contraction but rather to skin changes due to water exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cadaveric spasm occurs immediately after death without a phase of relaxation and is typically seen in the muscles of the hands, often indicating a struggle before death.

questions.text: All the following side effects of lithium, likely to occur after 1 year of treatment except- (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tardive Dyskinesia

 

Lithium, a commonly used mood stabilizer, is associated with several side effects that may occur after prolonged treatment. However, tardive dyskinesia is not a typical side effect of lithium.

 

Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements, usually of the face and tongue. It is more commonly associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications, particularly first-generation antipsychotics, and not with lithium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tremors are a common side effect of lithium that may occur after prolonged treatment.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism is a well-known side effect of lithium, which can develop after an extended period of treatment.

 

Option D. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is another potential side effect of lithium that may manifest after a year of treatment. Lithium can affect the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine, leading to excessive thirst and urination (polyuria).

 

Educational Objective:

 

While tremors, hypothyroidism, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are potential side effects of lithium that may occur after a year of treatment, tardive dyskinesia is typically associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum blues

 

Postpartum blues, or "baby blues," typically present within a 3-5 days post-delivery with mood swings, tearfulness, and mild insomnia. These symptoms resolve within a week or two.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postpartum depression: Is more severe and persistent, lasting beyond 2 weeks, often requiring intervention.

 

Option C. Postpartum psychosis: Is a rare, severe condition manifesting with hallucinations, delusions, and potential risk to the infant.

 

Option D. Postpartum anxiety: Involves excessive worry about the baby's well-being, often without the characteristic mood swings of the blues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Textbook of Women’s Reproductive Mental Health, Page No 352

questions.text: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The optimal time for determining the type of twin pregnancy through ultrasound is between 11+0 to 13+6 weeks, when the crown-rump length (CRL) is between 45 to 84 mm. This period allows for the most accurate dating and assessment of chorionicity, which is crucial for the management and outcome of twin pregnancies.

 

  • Chorionicity: The type of twin pregnancy (dichorionic or monochorionic) is determined by examining the thickness of the membrane at the site of insertion.
    • Lambda (λ) sign: Indicates a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
    • Inverted T sign: Indicates a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best time to determine the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Ref: Page no 2190, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: An 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia presented to the hospital, his BP is 88/68 mm Hg, Serum K+ is 6 mEq/L, serum sodium is 120 mEq/L. Patient was started on intravenous fluids. What additional specific therapy will you add?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydrocortisone

 

The presentation of an 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension (BP is 88/68 mm Hg, which is low for this age), hyperkalemia (serum K of 6 mEq/L), and hyponatremia (serum sodium of 120 mEq/L) is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This is a common form of CAH and can lead to a decrease in cortisol and aldosterone production, with an accompanying increase in adrenal androgens.

 

Given this clinical picture, the specific therapy to be added would include:

 

  1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: This is critical to suppress the overproduction of adrenal androgens. Hydrocortisone is commonly used, especially in pediatric patients, due to its short duration of action and lower impact on growth.

  2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone is usually added to manage the aldosterone deficiency, which is contributing to the hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.

  3. Sodium Chloride Supplements: In some cases, especially in infants and young children, additional sodium chloride supplements may be necessary to manage hyponatremia.

  4. Monitoring and Adjustment: Regular monitoring of electrolytes, blood pressure, and growth is necessary to adjust therapy accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Potassium Binding Resins: While these can be used to treat hyperkalemia, they do not address the underlying cause of the electrolyte imbalance in this scenario, which is likely due to aldosterone deficiency. Therefore, it would not be the first choice.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This is used primarily for heart failure and certain arrhythmias, not for the conditions described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Calcium Gluconate: This is used in the acute management of severe hyperkalemia to stabilize cardiac membranes. While it might be used in an emergency setting for life-threatening hyperkalemia, it does not address the underlying cause in this case and is not a long-term management strategy.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone (option a), as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone, as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/314

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs is not used in HIV & hepatitis B co-infection? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Abacavir

 

HLA B 57:01 mutation is associated with hypersensitivity to abacavir.

 

Abacavir is used in PLHIV with renal failure however is not effective against HBV.

 

Other options:

 

Option A, C, D inhibit both HIV reverse transcriptase and HBV DNA polymerase, thereby, inhibiting their replication.

 

M184V mutation results in resistance to Lamivudine, emtricitabine. However, increases susceptibility to tenofovir, zidovudine and also reduces rate of viral replication (Beneficial). Hence addition of boosted protease inhibitor + lamivudine is continued in such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the treatment of patients with HIV and hepatitis B co-infection, abacavir is not used due to its lack of efficacy against HBV. Instead, drugs like tenofovir, lamivudine, and emtricitabine, which have dual activity against both viruses, are preferred.

 

Reference: NACO 2021 HIV Care and treatment guidelines

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night blindness is a late feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a group of hereditary disorders that cause progressive degeneration of the retina, specifically affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones).

 

Night blindness is a late feature: This is incorrect. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is an early feature of RP. Patients often present with difficulties in dark adaptation and night vision long before significant peripheral vision loss occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave: Electroretinography (ERG) in RP patients shows decreased amplitude of both the a wave (originating from rods and cones) and the b wave (originating from bipolar cells).

 

Option B. Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy: RP typically starts with rod dysfunction, which later involves the cones.

 

Option C. Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision: RP usually presents with mid-peripheral vision loss, which progresses to peripheral vision loss and eventually central vision loss, leading to tunnel vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: A statistician is examining the scores of a recent standardized test to assess the variability in student performance. She is particularly interested in understanding the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest mark achieved. Which statistical measure should she use to directly determine this? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Range

 

  • Range is expressed as minimum - maximum (or maximum – minimum) values in a given set of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: It is given as square of standard deviation (Deviation of each value from the standard value).

 

Option B. Coefficient of variation (COV): It is a measure used to compare relative variability.

 

Option D. Interquartile range: Quartiles divide the distribution into 4 equal groups. The difference between Q1 and Q3 gives the interquartile range.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.

choices.text: Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba → Lochia Rubra
Lochia Serosa → Lochia Rubra → Lochia Alba
Lochia Rubra → Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba
Lochia Rubra → Lochia Alba → Lochia Serosa

questions.text: Mark the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium: (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lochia Rubra → Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba

 

Explanation:

 

Lochia is vaginal discharge after delivery.

 

It is composed of sloughed off decidua, blood, necrotic debris and secretions of the cervixand vagina.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of lochia during the puerperium is Lochia Rubra (red, first 3-4 days), Lochia Serosa (yellowish-brownish, 5-9 days), and Lochia Alba (white, lasts 10-28 days).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th Edition page 170

choices.text: Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

questions.text: A patient who had kidney stones removed presents with flank pain 4-5 years postoperatively and a foreign body is observed on imaging. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

 

The patient presents with flank pain years after having kidney stones removed, and imaging reveals a foreign body, likely a retained double J ureteric stent. Double J stents are often placed during procedures to manage kidney or ureteric stones to ensure urine drainage but should be removed once they are no longer needed.

 

The appropriate management in this case is to perform an endoscopy to remove the retained stent. Retaining a stent for too long can cause complications such as stone formation on the stent, obstruction, or infection, which explains the patient's current symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparotomy and Cystoscopic removal: Not required in this situation

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is incorrect as it is used to assess the urethra, not the ureter or kidneys. It is used for diagnosing urethral strictures or ruptures.

 

Option D. Leave the foreign body inside: This is incorrect and not a viable option as the foreign body (stent) is causing symptoms and potential complications, and must be removed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopy is the appropriate procedure for the removal of a retained ureteric stent, which can cause complications if left inside the body for too long.

choices.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.text: The WHO-created slogan 'Perform Correctly,' regarding initial snake bite assistance, includes everything listed below except for which one? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Incisions

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound (incisions, suction, rubbing, tattooing, vigorous cleaning, massage, application of herbs or chemicals, cryotherapy, cautery) as this may introduce infection, increase absorption of the venom and increase local bleeding.

 

First Aid treatment outside the hospital setting has very limited role in snake bite management. The first aid treatment can be divided in three categories:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Reassurance: Many snake bites are caused by non-venomous snakes. And even after most venomous snake bites, the patient can be saved the risk of death is not immediate. If the patient gets panicked his heart rate would increase which in term would spread the venom rapidly.

 

Option B) Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite: Detailed history will be helpful to know the type of snake Detailed history in snakebite is essential to delineate treatment options moving forward. Information to obtain includes the timing and location of bite, the onset of any symptoms, and any first aid administered in field. Take a past medical history with detail to which medications they are on, especially anti-platelet / anti-coagulant medications, and any allergies that would prohibit from receiving antivenom.

 

Option C) Go to hospital: Main treatment of snake bite can be given in hospital only (Anti-snake venom, airway maintenance, fluids etc.)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound. Always reassure the patient, immobilize the limb, and seek medical help immediately without attempting harmful interventions like making incisions or applying chemicals.

questions.text: What type of particles does a linear accelerator use? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) X rays

 

  • This is the correct answer. Linear accelerators use high-energy X rays to treat cancer. The X rays are generated by accelerating electrons and colliding them with a metal target. The resulting high-energy photons are directed to conform to a tumor’s shape, minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue.
  • A linear accelerator primarily uses X rays for therapeutic purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neutron: Neutrons are neutral particles that do not have an electrical charge. They are typically used in neutron therapy, a specialized and less common form of radiotherapy that targets certain types of cancer.

 

Option B. Proton: Proton therapy is another form of radiation therapy that uses protons rather than X rays. It is highly precise and is used to treat specific types of cancers, especially in sensitive or hard-to-reach areas.

 

Option D. Gamma Rays: These are typically not used in linear accelerators. Gamma rays are similar to X rays but originate from the nucleus of an atom. They are used in other types of radiation treatments, such as those involving radioactive isotopes in brachytherapy or stereotactic radiosurgery.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Linear accelerators are crucial in modern oncology, allowing high precision in targeting tumors while sparing healthy tissue, using high-energy X rays derived from accelerated electrons.

questions.text: Identify the brace given in the following image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Milwaukee brace

 

  • The brace given in the image is Milwaukee brace that is used for scoliosis.

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae and classified by its anatomic location, in either the thoracic or lumbar spine, with rare involvement of the cervical spine.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)
       
  • Types of scoliosis:

 

 

  • Clinical Findings:
    • Scoliosis in adolescents does not typically cause significant pain. If a patient has significant pain, she/he should be evaluated to rule out the possibility of some other disorder such as infection or tumor.
    • Deformity of the rib cage and asymmetry of the waistline are clinically evident for curvatures of 30 degrees or more.
    • Lesser curves may be detected through a forward bending test (Adam’s test), which is designed to detect early abnormalities of rotation that may not be apparent when the patient is standing erect.
    • Rotation of the spine may be measured with a scoliometer. Rotation is associated with a marked rib hump as the lateral curvature increases in severity.
       
  • Imaging:
    • Radiographs taken of the entire spine in the standing position in both the posterior anterior (PA) and lateral planes are the most valuable for diagnosis.
    • Usually, a primary curve is evident with compensatory curvature to balance the body.
    • Skeletal maturity can be assessed by the Risser sign. A radiograph is employed to see how far the patient's iliac apophysis has progressed from the anterior superior iliac spine. During development, the iliac apophysis first appears laterally and grows medially. The stages are Risser I-V, where Risser V denotes that the apophysis has completely fused with the iliac crest and therefore, skeletal maturity can be assumed hence, further progression of curve of scoliosis will not take place.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of scoliosis depends on the curve magnitude, skeletal maturity, and risk of progression.
    • Specific management is dependent on the Cobb angle, measured on a standing PA X-ray of the spine.
    • Brace treatment is restricted to immature children in an attempt to prevent curve progression during further skeletal growth. So, it is indicated in Growing adolescents (Risser 0, 1 or 2) who, on presentation, have curves in range of 30-45 degrees or who have had documented progression exceeding 5 degrees in curve that initially measured 20-30 degrees.
    • TLSOs are the most commonly used orthoses today, but their use is restricted to patients whose curve apex is at or below T7.
    • Suspensory plaster cast of sayre, Rissers cast hinge or turnbuckle cast of Hibbs and Kisser, Milwaukee brace, Boston brace, Charleston night-time bending brace, Wilmington brace and thoraco-lumbo- sacral orthoses (TLSOs) are used to treat idiopathic scoliosis (Lower Dorsal scoliosis > Lumbar Scoliosis).
    • Surgical treatment consists of corrective osteotomies and fusion.
    • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added.
    • Spinal fusions are delayed as long as possible in young children through the use of casting, bracing, and growth modulating surgeries such as growing rods or vertical expandable prosthetic titanium ribs (VEPTR).

 

 

  • Milwaukee Brace: 
    • The Milwaukee brace is an active corrective spinal orthosis.
    • It consists of a neck ring with a throat mould and two occipital pads to avoid a high pressure in the neck.
    • Other elements are a plastic pelvic girdle, aluminium uprights, leather L-shaped thoracic pads and metal bars in the front and in the back.
    • It is used in the treatment of postural disorders like idiopathic scoliosis or Scheuerman disease.
    • The brace is normally prescribed for children, with a postural disorder, who have not reached their growth spurt or who are in their fast growing period.
    • It is not used for adults or adolescents already beyond their growth spurt, as it will have no effect.
    • If the spinal curve has a Cobb angle between 20° and 40°, it is an indication to use a brace.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The brace shown in the image in the question is of a Milwaukee brace, which is used to treat scoliosis in adolescent children.

questions.text: What does ‘H’ indicate in a patient presenting with a history of EHEC O157:H7? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flagella

 

In the nomenclature of bacteria, specifically Escherichia coli (E. coli) strains like EHEC O157, the ‘H’ antigen refers to the flagellar antigen. Flagella are whip-like structures that allow bacteria to be motile. The ‘O’ antigen represents the somatic (cell wall) antigen, which is associated with the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) layer of the bacterial cell wall. Therefore, the ‘H’ antigen is specifically linked to flagella, which is crucial for bacterial motility and plays a role in pathogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Capsule: The capsule is a polysaccharide layer that surrounds some bacterial cells, providing protection against the host immune system. It is not related to the ‘H’ antigen.

 

Option B. Fimbriae: Fimbriae are short, hair-like structures on the bacterial surface that assist in adherence to surfaces and are not related to the ‘H’ antigen. They are different from flagella and do not contribute to motility.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharide: Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is part of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria and is associated with the ‘O’ antigen, not the ‘H’ antigen. It plays a significant role in the immune response but is unrelated to bacterial motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In bacterial antigen classification, the ‘H’ antigen corresponds to flagella, which are essential for motility.

choices.text: 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 17 alpha hydroxylase, 17,20 lyase
20, 22 desmolase, 17,20 lyase, 17 alpha hydroxylase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase

questions.text: Choose the right sequence of steps in the conversion of cholesterol to testosterone (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 17 alpha hydroxylase, 17,20 lyase

 

For the sequence of reactions for cholesterol to testosterone conversion, refer to pathway below:

 

 

For change in number of carbons refer to diagram below:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for the conversion of cholesterol to testosterone involves the enzymes 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, 17 alpha hydroxylase, and 17,20 lyase in that specific order.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with dyslipidemia has persistently elevated triglyceride levels (600 mg/dL) despite treatment with rosuvastatin. What will be the next step? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gemfibrozil

 

In cases where a patient has dyslipidemia with persistently elevated triglyceride levels, particularly above 500 mg/dL, there is a significant risk of developing pancreatitis. The primary goal in such situations is to lower the triglyceride levels to mitigate this risk. Fibrates, such as gemfibrozil or fenofibrate, are the treatment of choice for reducing triglyceride levels effectively. They act by decreasing the hepatic secretion of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and increasing the clearance of triglycerides from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is used to reduce low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels. It works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. While it is effective for lowering LDL, it is not the first-line treatment for elevated triglycerides.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin, or vitamin B3, was previously used to lower both LDL and triglyceride levels. However, it is no longer commonly used in practice due to its side effects and lack of significant additional benefit over other treatments.

 

Option D. Cholestyramine: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant that is primarily used to lower LDL cholesterol. It is not particularly effective in reducing triglyceride levels and can cause gastrointestinal side effects, making it a less favorable option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with triglyceride levels above 500 mg/dL, fibrates such as gemfibrozil are the preferred treatment to reduce the risk of pancreatitis.
